SDS255H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS255H1-F-20169.courseTitle: History and Perspectives in Sexual Diversity (formerly UNI255H1)
SDS255H1-F-20169.courseDescription: An interdisciplinary examination of sexuality across cultures and periods. How are sexualities represented? How are they suppressed or celebrated? How and why are they labeled as straight, gay, lesbian, bisexual, queer, or perverse? How do sexualities change with ethnicity, class, and gender?

SDS256H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS256H1-S-20169.courseTitle: Social Scientific Approaches to Sexuality (formerly UNI256H1)
SDS256H1-S-20169.courseDescription: A cross-cultural perspective on the methodological and theoretical approaches used by social scientists to study human sexuality and gendered diversity.

SDS345H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS345H1-F-20169.courseTitle: Sex and the Epidemic: Social Work, HIV, and Human Sexuality (formerly UNI345H1)
SDS345H1-F-20169.courseDescription: HIV has forever changed the way human beings understand sexuality. Through a social justice lens, this course examines the nature of community norms, laws, popular media, and the academy to explore how the epidemic has impacted the provision of social services in relation to the diversity of human sexuality.

SDS346H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS346H1-F-20169.courseTitle: Feminist and Queer Approaches to Technology (formerly UNI346H1)
SDS346H1-F-20169.courseDescription: What do electronic technologies mean for feminist and queer identity, activism, sociability, art, and politics? This course considers a range of critical pressure points central to digital studies, including social networking, participatory media, digital archives, databases, new media activism, performance, embodiment, and representations of race, gender, and sexuality in electronic contexts.
SDS346H1-F-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1 or permission of the instructor

SDS354H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS354H1-F-20169.courseTitle: Theories of Sexuality I: The Foundations (formerly UNI354H1)
SDS354H1-F-20169.courseDescription: A survey of classic western theories of sexuality; each theory is examined in terms of the practices it allows and prohibits. Under consideration are not only the descriptive and/or prescriptive aspects of a particular framework but its epistemic grounds, and implications for understanding identity, body, community, and state.

SDS355H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS355H1-S-20169.courseTitle: Theories of Sexuality II: Contemporary Perspectives (formerly UNI355H1)
SDS355H1-S-20169.courseDescription: An integrated survey of some ways in which sexuality has been theorized recently. How have desire and its identities been conceptualized and deployed? What are the implications for psychoanalysis, feminism, and cultural production? What interconnections are yet to be made between sexuality and the markers of gender, race, and class?
SDS355H1-S-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1 or permission of the instructor

SDS365H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS365H1-F-20169.courseDescription: The course explores the legal regulation of sexuality. How does law understand, constitute and regulate sex, sexuality and sexual diversity? It will consider the role of different types of regulation, including criminal law, family law and constitutional law, and explore issues ranging from sex work and pornography to same sex marriage to transgender discrimination.

SDS375H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS375H1-F-20169.courseTitle: Special Topics in Sexual Diversity Studies A (formerly UNI375H1)
SDS375H1-F-20169.courseDescription: Topics vary from year to year depending on instructor. This seminar is intended to expose students in the Sexual Diversity Studies program to topics that may not be covered by permanent university courses.
SDS375H1-F-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1 or permission of the instructor

SDS376H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS376H1-S-20169.courseTitle: Special Topics in Sexual Diversity Studies B (formerly UNI376H1)
SDS376H1-S-20169.courseDescription: Topics vary from year to year depending on instructor. This seminar is intended to expose students in the Sexual Diversity Studies program to topics that may not be covered by permanent university courses.
SDS376H1-S-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1 or permission of the instructor

LEC-0101.subtitle: Intro to Queer of Colour Critique

SDS377H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS377H1-S-20169.courseDescription: This multidisciplinary course examines multiple lesbian identities that have varied in time and place. The course will pose such questions as: What does lesbian mean? Why have changes occurred in meaning? How has the identity of lesbian been culturally represented and politically expressed in various social and political contexts? It will also take up contemporary theoretical, cultural, and political understandings of lesbianism.

SDS378H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS378H1-S-20169.courseTitle: Queer Youth Studies in Education (formerly UNI378H1)
SDS378H1-S-20169.courseDescription: Experiences of queer youth are explored in various education settings through academic research, personal essays, and visual and performing arts to investigate how queer youth define themselves, what they are learning, the curriculum and pedagogy used in the learning process and the possibilities of said learning for social change, individual and community well-being.
SDS378H1-S-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1 or permission of the instructor

SDS379H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS379H1-S-20169.courseDescription: Queer Pop Culture seeks to represent a diversity of approaches in queer popular cultures, exploring the ways in which LGBTQ subjectivities are represented in literature, film, and the media, as well as the ways in which sexual identity is inextricably bound up with other axes of identity.
SDS379H1-S-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1/UNI255H1/UNI256H1 or permission of the instructor

SDS380H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS380H1-F-20169.courseTitle: Sexual Diversity in a Global Context
SDS380H1-F-20169.courseDescription: An exploration of LGBTQ rights and changes in social and cultural responses to sexual diversity in varied regional, national, and cultural contexts, potentially including Africa, Latin America, South and East Asia, and Eastern Europe.  The role of transnational linkages and networks will also be considered in effecting change.
SDS380H1-F-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1 or permission of the instructor

SDS390H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS390H1-F-20169.courseDescription: Explores the role of sports and wellness programs in promoting or impeding social inclusion, as well as their role in community building among sexual minorities. It will consider the ways that sexuality has been framed or regulated in sports, as well as the challenges to such limits from among athletes, LGBT activists, and others.
SDS390H1-F-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1 (UNI255H1/UNI256H1) or permission from the instructor.

SDS458H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS458H1-F-20169.courseTitle: Research Essay in Sexual Diversity (formerly UNI458H1)
SDS458H1-F-20169.courseDescription: A research essay under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity, the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SDS458H1-F-20169.webTimetableInstructions: For E indicator courses: please contact Rebecca Thorpe in UC251, Monday to Friday, 9:00am to 4:30pm for further information or email: sexual.diversity@utoronto.ca

SDS458H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS458H1-S-20169.courseTitle: Research Essay in Sexual Diversity (formerly UNI458H1)
SDS458H1-S-20169.courseDescription: A research essay under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity, the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SDS458H1-S-20169.webTimetableInstructions: For E indicator courses: please contact Rebecca Thorpe in UC251, Monday to Friday, 9:00am to 4:30pm for further information or email: sexual.diversity@utoronto.ca

SDS459Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS459Y1-Y-20169.courseTitle: Honours Essay in Sexual Diversity (formerly UNI459Y1)
SDS459Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: A major research essay prepared over the course of two academic terms (one year); under the supervision of a faculty member with knowledge of sexual diversity; the proposal and supervisor subject to the approval of the SDS Program Director. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SDS459Y1-Y-20169.webTimetableInstructions: For E indicator courses: please contact Rebecca Thorpe in UC251, Monday to Friday, 9:00am to 4:30pm for further information or email: sexual.diversity@utoronto.ca

SDS460Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS460Y1-Y-20169.courseTitle: Advanced Research in Sexual Diversity Studies (formerly UNI460H1)
SDS460Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: A capstone for majors and specialists who will work closely with SDS faculty in developing their own research project while participating in this seminar and learning about key debates, methodologies, and ethical issues in conducting research in SDS. Students will learn to write proposals, ethics reviews, grants and other relevant documents. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
SDS460Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1(70%)/SDS256H1(70%)UNI255H1(70%)/UNI256H1(70%) and one 300-level SDS/UNI Sexual Diversity Studies course

SDS477H1-S-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS477H1-S-20169.courseDescription: This course introduces students to Trans Studies as an emerging interdisciplinary field of scholarship from various angles: academic, activist, socio-historical, and clinical. Students will develop their abilities to assess representations of trans and intersexed people and social issues, taking into account how race, citizenship, gender, sexuality, culture and dis/ability are materially and socially constructed together to give meaning to the category trans.

SDS478H1-F-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS478H1-F-20169.courseDescription: This course explores how sexuality and gender are performed in and through a variety of musics, including popular musics and opera. Topics include music as sexual politics; vicissitudes of queer theory in music; homo-musical communities and groups; music technologies and sexualities; gay/lesbian icons in popular musics; lesbian/gay desire and divas.

SDS490Y1-Y-20169.orgName: Sexual Diversity Studies, Mark S. Bonham Centre (SDS) (JNS) (JPS) (JPU) (JSU)
SDS490Y1-Y-20169.courseDescription: A service learning course with student placements in various LGBT community organizations alongside regular classroom seminars to look at the politics of engagement, active citizenship, mobilization, archiving community histories, accessibility, belonging, activism, and philanthropy.
SDS490Y1-Y-20169.prerequisite: SDS255H1/SDS256H1 (UNI255H1/UNI256H1) and at least 1 FCE in SDS at the third-year level or permission of the instructor. For Majors and Specialists.
SDS490Y1-Y-20169.exclusion: SDS456Y1: Special Topics: Engaging our Communities (2015-16)
